Award.AbstractNarration:
SES 0960617
John D. McCarthy
Pennsylvania State University

Christopher P. Scheitle
Pennsylvania State University

Research on organized American religion has focused almost exclusively on congregations and denominations. This research aims to explore an understudied but increasingly significant type of religious organization: 'parachurch' or nonprofit religious organizations (NROs). The investigators draw upon previous work on the creation of organizations to develop hypotheses about how spiritual entrepreneurs start new religious enterprises, as well as how community contexts might affect rates of NRO creation. A data set will be assembled that will allow the exploration of the sources, processes and consequences of spiritual entrepreneurialism. The investigators will survey two cohorts of newly registered NROs about their founders, founding decisions and activities, and the current status of their organization such as whether it remains viable and, if so, its size, structure and focus. Finally, a sub-set of respondents will be contacted for more extensive open-ended telephone and in-person interviews.

Broader Impacts
The research has the potential of illuminating an important domain of religious and nonprofit activity in the U.S. that contributes importantly to its religious and social vitality while at the same time integrating the study of profit making entrepreneurialism with spiritual entrepreneurialism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project’s goal was to understand entrepreneurialism as it is embodied within the population of public charities (sometimes called 501c3s or just “nonprofits”). There are nearly one million public charities in the United States, and this number has grown rapidly over the years. If we define entrepreneurialism as individuals establishing new organizations, then the public charity sector would seem to be rich with entrepreneurialism.

Specifically, the project focused on public charities classified as religion-related in mission or identity. We aimed to understand the individuals who create new organizations within this sector, how they go about creating their organizations, and how variations in types of founders or founding processes shape organizations. We focused on this subset of public charities both because religion-related organizations represent a large segment of the population and because these organizations have been recognized as increasingly important in understanding American religion.

We completed a national mail survey of two groups of religion-related public charities: those founded during a twelve month period in 2003-2004 and those founded during a twelve month period in 2009-2010. The survey asked questions about the founder, his or her background, the process by which the organization was created, the organization’s activities, and the organization’s structure. We also conducted 60 interviews with founders and leaders of religion-related public charities. These interviews provided more depth and insights than one might get from multiple choice questions on a survey. Finally, we examined created a database of foundings based on IRS records across a ten year period. We used this database to better understand how a community’s characteristics increase or decrease entrepreneurialism in the religious nonprofit sector.  

So far we have produced four published or accepted articles for peer-reviewed scholarly journals. One of these articles examined how cognitive narratives play a role in founders’ understanding of their founding experiences. This is often referred to as “sense-making.” We found in both our survey and interview data that founders who utilized certain narratives, such as feeling religiously called to create their organization, showed signs of greater determination and resilience within the founding process. Another article examined how founders’ perceptions of competition shaped, or don’t shape, their efforts. Although four papers have been published or accepted for publication so far, others are under review or in preparation. One such paper examines communities with dense clusters of religion-related public charities. These communities include Colorado Springs, CO, Nashville, TN, and Tulsa, OK. We analyze this phenomenon through research on industrial clusters (e.g., moviemaking in Hollywood, car manufacturing in Detroit, etc.).

We also produced a descriptive project report that we provided to all the survey participants (i.e., the founders and leaders of the religion-related public charities) that we hope provided some insights for how their organization and founding compares to peer organizations. Select figures from this report have been included with this report.

In addition to its research goals, the project provided educational and training opportunities to two graduate students and eight undergraduate students. The de-identified survey data produced from the project will also be made available to other scholars or interested parties so that the project will continue to provide insights beyond the formal bounds of the grant period.
